alert.note: Alert for Costilla; Huerfano (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 08 at 2:48PM MDT until August 08 at 6:45PM MDT by NWS Pueblo
info.description: The National Weather Service in Pueblo has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... The Spring Burn Scar in... Northeastern Costilla County in south central Colorado... Southwestern Huerfano County in southeastern Colorado... * Until 645 PM MDT. * At 248 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Spring Burn Scar. The expected rainfall rate is 0.75 to 1 inch in 1 hour. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the warning area will cause mud slides near steep terrain. The mud slide can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Spring Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Spring Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Spring Burn Scar south of Highway 160 in Costilla county, Spring Burn Scar south of Highway 160 in Huerfano county, Indian Creek on the southeastern Spring Burn Scar, Spring Burn Scar north of Highway 160, La Veta Pass and Cuchara. This includes the following high risk locations... Sulphur Springs on Indian Creek, County Road 421 near Indian Creek, South Abeyta Creek near County Road 443, South Abeyta Creek near County Road 442, South Abeyta Creek near County Road 441 and Pass Creek Road. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...0.75-1 INCH IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall will cause extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks...streams...and ditches in the Spring Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters...climb to safety. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
